title: 107_s1568
content: The Act titled "Cyberterrorism Prevention Act of 2001" aims to deter and prevent cyberterrorism in connection with computers. The Act "Cyberterrorism Prevention Act of 2001" is amending section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, to clarify the protection of protected computers by specifying conditions for causing loss exceeding $5,000 in value. The Cyberterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 is amending section 1030 of title 18, United States Code to specify conditions for causing loss exceeding $5,000 in value, protection from extortion, and penalties for offenses. The Cyberterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 is amending penalties in section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, including changes to fines and offenses punishable under the law. The Cyberterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 is amending penalties in section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, including fines and imprisonment for offenses under subsection (a)(5)(A)(i) and (a)(5)(A)(ii), with maximum penalties of 10, 5, and 20 years respectively. The Cyberterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 is amending penalties in section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, including fines and imprisonment for offenses under subsection (a)(5)(A)(i) and (a)(5)(A)(ii), with maximum penalties of 10, 5, and 20 years respectively. Definitions in subsection (e) are also being amended to include the term 'damage' as any impairment to data, a program, a system, or information. The Cyberterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 is amending penalties in section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, including fines and imprisonment for offenses related to unauthorized access to a computer. The new paragraphs define terms like 'conviction', 'loss', and 'person' to clarify the scope of the law. The Cyberterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 is amending penalties in section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, including fines and imprisonment for offenses related to unauthorized access to a computer. The new paragraphs define terms like 'conviction', 'loss', and 'person' to clarify the scope of the law. Damages in civil actions for violations of this section are limited to economic damages and exclude actions for negligent design or manufacture of computer hardware, software, or firmware. SEC. 3 amends Section 2707(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code to include a governmental entity request under section 2703(f). SEC. 4 focuses on the development and support of cyber security forensic activities. The Director of the FBI will develop regional computer forensic laboratories to provide forensic examinations, training, and assistance for investigating computer-related crimes. The FBI will develop regional computer forensic laboratories to assist in investigating computer-related crimes, including sharing expertise with state and local law enforcement. $50,000,000 is authorized annually for these purposes.
